item.title: England's Tyrone Mings criticises Patel over racism response
item.description: England's Tyrone Mings accuses the home secretary of "pretending" to be disgusted about racist abuse.

item.title: Marcus Rashford: Hundreds of messages left on mural
item.description: The artwork was vandalised following England's defeat to Italy in the Euro 2020 final.

item.title: Covid: Bus and train firms must decide whether to require masks
item.description: Masks will not be legally required on public transport when Covid restrictions are eased in England.

item.title: The EU countries 'pushing back' asylum seekers at sea
item.description: Greece is accused of sending thousands back to Turkey without allowing them to apply for asylum.

item.title: Covid in Scotland: Sturgeon to announce decision on restrictions
item.description: The First Minister will confirm whether Scotland's levels will be changed on 19 July as planned.

item.title: Covid-19: Transport companies to decide on masks and Scotland rules review
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Tuesday morning.

item.title: Foreign aid: MPs to vote on cut to UK budget
item.description: They will choose between restoring spending to previous levels or tying it to government borrowing.

item.title: Iraq hospital fire: Protests as Covid ward blaze kills more than 60
item.description: Angry relatives of the victims have been protesting outside the now devastated Covid isolation ward.

item.title: Hamilton report aims to boost motorsport diversity
item.description: Lewis Hamilton says that helping motorsport become more diverse will be "the most valuable" thing he has achieved in his career.

item.title: Flash floods: Parts of London receive a month of rain in one day
item.description: Cars are submerged in water in some areas while train services have also been cancelled.

item.title: Texas Democrats flee state to block Republican voting law
item.description: Republicans in the state are proposing some of the most restrictive voting laws in the US.

item.title: Met Police seize record Â£180m of cryptocurrency in London
item.description: The seizure is the largest of its kind in the UK - beating the previous record set just weeks ago.

item.title: The Papers: 'Ugly face of football' and 'freedom day' in England
item.description: Tuesday's papers react to three England players being subjected to racist abuse.

item.title: Bank scammer threatens BBC reporter over the phone
item.description: A fraudster threatens a BBC reporter during a call supposedly from his bank after a text scam.

item.title: Flash floods in parts of London leaves cars submerged as roads fill with water
item.description: Heavy rain has caused flash floods in parts of London, leaving cars submerged and roads filled with water.

item.title: Nadiya Hussain: 'I've wanted to bleach the brown out of me'
item.description: Nadiya Hussain talks to comedian Ali Shahalom about being British Bangladeshi in 2021.

item.title: Ghana's Kojo Marfo: Sell-out show for butcher-turned-painter
item.description: He's got rock star fans and two sold-out shows to his name, but Kojo Marfo prefers life's simple joys.

item.title: Why people in Eswatini are calling for change
item.description: Dozens of people have died in recent protests calling for reform of Eswatini's absolute monarchy.

item.title: In numbers: Life in Afghanistan after America leaves
item.description: How did 20 years of war between the US and the Taliban change Afghanistan?

item.title: How your driving might reveal early signs of Alzheimer's
item.description: Research shows how small changes in the way you drive could expose preclinical signs of disease.

item.title: US heatwave: Could US and Canada see the worst wildfires yet?
item.description: The annual fire season has barely started - and there are claims that 2021 might be the worst year yet.

item.title: Plastic surgery booming in China despite the dangers
item.description: Young people are using social media apps to plan cosmetic procedures which don't always meet expectations.

item.title: The myth of India's population explosion
item.description: India's most populous state has a contentious plan for curbing population growth. But is it necessary?

item.title: England 'must be let off the leash'
item.description: After losing the Euro 2020 final on penalties to Italy, BBC Sport's Phil McNulty looks at how manager Gareth Southgate can take England to the next step.

item.title: Capitol riots: What we have learned six months on
item.description: Arrests and probes continue as some conservatives seek to cast 6 January in a different light.

item.title: I will never apologise for who I am - Rashford
item.description: England and Manchester United forward Marcus Rashford says he "will never apologise for who I am" after receiving racist abuse following England's Euro 2020 final loss to Italy.

item.title: What are the new sports at the Tokyo Olympic Games?
item.description: With 34 new events in total added to the Tokyo Olympic programme, BBC Sport takes a look at what's new.

item.title: Euro 2020: Phillips' 83km, Ronaldo's records and Pedri's passes - the best stats from the summer
item.description: As the dust begins to settle on Euro 2020, BBC Sport looks at some of the standout stats from this summer's tournament.

item.title: 'I had to learn to walk again' - the surfer who overcame a traumatic brain injury to reach Olympics
item.description: Australian surfer Owen Wright suffered a traumatic brain injury in 2015. Now he's heading to the Olympics.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: Ovie Soko presents Olympic basketball greats
item.description: Ovie Soko presents a rundown of basketball legends to have won medals at the Olympic Games.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Team GB Truths with triathletes Jess Learmonth & Georgia Taylor-Brown
item.description: Jess Learmonth and Georgia Taylor-Brown are team-mates and friends, but can they tell if the other is lying?

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Health Secretary Sajid Javid has confirmed government plans for lifting the remaining Covid restrictions in England.

item.title: Should I still wear a face mask or covering and what are the rules?
item.description: People will be expected to wear masks in crowded indoor spaces after 19 July.

item.title: Vaccine passports: How can the NHS Covid Pass prove I've had both my Covid jabs?
item.description: Proof of vacciniation will be used to avoid certain Covid requirements, such as having to self-isolate in some circumstances.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: The working from home advice in England is set to change on 19 July.

item.title: How many cases are in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: 'Indians don't talk about sex - so I help them'
item.description: An Indian sex coach says parents turn to her for advice as sex education is not available in schools.

item.title: Fire lookouts: The US Forest Service lookouts watching for fires
item.description: In remote towers, US Forest Service lookouts act as an early warning system for forest fires.

item.title: Virgin Galactic: Richard Branson's long, winding path to space
item.description: The BBC tracks the long, winding road to Sir Richard Branson's flight to the edge of space.

item.title: Bibaa and Nicole: The life after death of two sisters
item.description: Bibaa Henry and Nicole Smallman died in a senseless attack. But they should not be remembered as victims.

item.title: Why Canada is reforming indigenous foster care
item.description: The residential school legacy has been linked to the overrepresentation of indigenous children in care.
